Question:
It was good to have the house full of people again; it had been far too quiet since the last of his seven daughters had left for college--seven daughters with seven different majors at seven different schools.  About the only thing they had in common was that they were each dating an athlete, although none of them played the same sport--one was even on his school's fencing team.  He was surprised all the boyfriends had come for Christmas dinner, but he supposed that since he was picking up the tab for the airfare, that a free trip to Hawaii in the winter had something to do with it.  Each of his first three daughters had gone to Ivy League schools--one even to his alma mater at Harvard; his next two ended up at the University of California, at Los Angeles and Berkeley; and his two youngest got accepted to schools abroad--the University of Tokyo had been a bit of a surprise.  Next year, after seven straight years--and for the first time this millennium--he wouldn't be attending a high-school graduation.
"Honey, we're ready to eat.  Can you get Hank, Ian, James and Kyle?  They're in the backyard playing football.  The other boys wanted to test themselves against the star quarterback," his wife called from the dining room.
The math major said, "I'll get them Dad!"
As everyone filed into the dining room, the oldest sister was rehashing the whose-school-and-major-is-better argument with her younger sister about whether Yale or Princeton was a better school and whether history or philosophy was a more useful major.  The argument was practically a Christmas tradition by now.
The table was arranged with the parents at the two ends and each of the couples seated across from each other with boys seated next to girls along each side.  As usual, Angelina and Danica were sitting next to their parents.  Curiously, all the athletes that used a ball in their sport were sitting on the same side of the table.  Christie, Electra and Edward took their seats first.
Once everyone was seated the youngest coyly observed, "I see the biologist is sitting between the two fighters but I'm sitting between the two best passers at the table."
"You'd better not make any passes yourself!" Farrah icily replied.  She hadn't forgiven her sister for stealing her boyfriend when they were in high school and was not happy to see her seated next to her boyfriend now.
"Lighten up, Farrah" the biology major joked.  "He wasn't even that cute."
"He was adorable!" the youngest interjected.
"Everyone's entitled to their opinion," said Brooke.  "Let's eat!"
The daughter in the middle seat stood up and said, "We have an announcement to make!" After a dramatic pause she screamed "we're getting married!" and flashed the new diamond ring on her finger.  The youngest sister squealed with delight at the news.  Her fiance joked to his future mother-in-law, "I think she said yes just so she can wear the monogrammed sweater you gave me for Christmas."  The baseball player next to her asked her fiance, "Wow, what'd that rock set you back?"
"This calls for a toast!" roared Dad.
"Oh Honey, that's wonderful news!" Mom gushed.  "I just happen to have some champagne right here.  Lars, I know you don't drink alcohol, but would you mind pouring some champagne for Gabrielle next to you?" the mother asked, handing the bottle to Lars on her left.  "Gabrielle, please pass the bottle around," she asked and then quickly added, "But no alcohol for my three babies, or anyone under 21 for that matter.  Honey, there's a store downtown that's having a sale on wedding dresses.  Will you have time to go look at some wedding dresses before you leave?"
"Sure Mom," her daughter answered.  "We have a late flight out, so I can do that on the day we leave."
"Michael and I are celebrating New Years Eve at the Sheraton, Waikiki," one of the girls announced.
"What a coincidence," said the boy sitting next to her.  "We're celebrating New Years at the Sheraton, Los Angeles.  It's within walking distance of our apartment so we won't have to worry if we drink too much."
"That sounds like a better plan than we have.  Somehow, just because my car holds a lot of people, I got roped into being the designated driver for the team" Danica said, looking pointedly at her boyfriend, who gestured to the boy from Princeton saying, "he gave me the idea!"
"Girls, your grandmother will be here on Sunday," the father announced.  "She'd really like to see you all."
"Sorry Dad," the business major replied, "we have to leave tomorrow.  There's a huge storm predicted to hit the Eastern United States this weekend and we need to get home before they close the airports.  I noticed that each couple is leaving on a different day for six days after we leave."
"Sir, we're leaving before Sunday also, so we won't be able to make it either.  I'm just glad we don't have to deal with that storm" said the wrestler.
The swimmer and water polo player announced their travel plans.  One of them remarked that even though his girlfriend and he were departing for Oxford University two days earlier, both couples would get home on the same day.
The physics major said "I'll be here to see grandma, but unfortunately we're heading back to California before you go look at the wedding gowns."
"Well I'm glad you'll at least be here to see your grandma, but I wish you could stay longer" the dad said.  "You know you're my favorite since you were my first to major in a physical science like me," he joked.  "I have a tee time at the club on Monday, it's too bad you won't be here," the father remarked to the golfer.  "Kyle's got a game next week but you don't," he said to the history major's boyfriend.  "How about you join me on the links?"
"Sure!" the boyfriend replied enthusiastically.
"Since we're leaving the day after him, if you've got room for two more Dad, we just happened to bring our clubs" the second oldest said, winking at her boyfriend.
"It's a foursome then!" her dad said happily.
Ian grumbled, "Hank you lucky dog, I've wanted to play that course for years!"
The boyfriend of the political science major laughed, "I'd like to play there also, but Ian, at least I won't have to travel as far as you to get another opportunity."
---------
Identify the boyfriend and his sport, the school, and major for each daughter.  Name the order that the daughters were born in and the day of the week that they leave to go home.  What is the seating arrangement at the dinner table?
Bonus question: what year is it?
Hint:
Pay attention to the flow of the conversation, but don't assume more than can be firmly established.
Also, some information relies on the following facts:
Christmas is on December 25th.
New Years Eve is celebrated (usually by drinking too much alcohol) on December 31st.
Swimming, fencing and wrestling are not games.  Football, baseball, water polo and golf are games played with a ball.
Fencing and wrestling are combat competitions.
The game of American football is not a collegiate sport outside the United States; the player that passes the ball is the quarterback; there are more than forty players on a football team.
Water polo is a game played in a pool with 7 players on each team; points are scored by throwing the ball into the opponents net, which is guarded by the goal keeper; the ball is moved across the pool either by swimming with it or passing it to another player.
Ivy League schools are located on the East Coast of the United States.  Harvard, Yale and Princeton are all Ivy League schools.
Oxford University is in Oxford, England.
Tokyo University is in Tokyo, Japan.
Los Angeles and Berkeley are cities in California.
Waikiki is a city in Hawaii.
Hawaii is in the Pacific Ocean.  The following are approximate distances from Hawaii:
Berkeley and Los Angeles ~ 2500 miles
Tokyo ~3900 miles
Yale, Harvard and Princeton ~5000 miles
England ~7000 miles
Biology and physics are physical sciences; none of the other majors is a physical science.
High school in America typically includes the last three or four years of school before college.
A designated driver remains sober in order to drive people who've had too much alcohol home.
A monogram is formed from the first letter of a person's first, last and (sometimes) middle names.
Human Solution:
From oldest to youngest the sisters are:
Who, Boyfriend, Sport, Major, School, Departure day
----------------------------------------------------------
Danica, Hank, Water Polo, History, Yale, Tue
Electra, Edward, Fencing, Philosophy, Princeton, Wed
Angelina, Lars, Golf, Business, Harvard, Fri
Gabrielle, James, Wrestling, Poly Sci., UCLA, Sat
Farrah, Kyle, Football, Physics, Berkeley, Mon.
Brooke, Michael, Baseball, Biology, Tokyo, Thu
Christie, Ian, Swimming, Math, Oxford, Sun
The seating arrangement is:
---------- Dad ----------
Hank.............Danica
Christie..........Ian
Kyle..............Farrah
Electra...........Edward
Michael..........Brooke
Gabrielle........James
Lars..............Angelina
---------- Mom ----------
The year is 2003.  This is the only year from 2000 to 2007 where Christmas is on a Thursday.

- Birth order: 1st (oldest) to 7th (youngest). 5th, 6th, 7th daughters are "three babies" under 21.

- Side 2 (Non-Ball Sports): 3 Boys (B), 4 Girls (G). Pattern G-B-G-B-G-B-G. Boyfriends on this side have girlfriends on Side 1.

- Non-Ball Sports: Fencing, Wrestling, Swimming.

- Lars is on Mom's left. Gabrielle is next to Lars. Assuming Mom is at one end of the table, Lars is the first or last person on a side. If Lars is a ball player (Side 1), he's B1 or B4. If B4, Gabrielle is G3.
  Side 1: B1(QB) - G1(Youngest) - B2(Water Polo) - G2(Engaged) - B3(Baseball) - G3(Gabrielle) - B4(Lars/Golfer).
  This fits "Lars on Mom's left" (Lars is B4, end of side) and "Gabrielle next to Lars" (Gabrielle is G3).
- Youngest daughter ("I'm sitting between the two best passers") sits between QB and Water Polo player. So Youngest is G1. QB is B1, WP is B2.
- Engaged daughter is in the middle seat (G2). Baseball player is next to her (B3).

  Angelina and Danica are at the ends of Side 2, next to parents.

Question:
The warden meets with 23 new prisoners when they arrive. He tells them, "You may meet today and plan a strategy. But after today, you will be in isolated cells and will have no communication with one another.
"In the prison there is a switch room which contains two light switches labeled A and B, each of which can be in either the 'on' or the 'off' position. BOTH SWITCHES ARE IN THEIR OFF POSITIONS NOW.*  The switches are not connected to anything.
"After today, from time to time whenever I feel so inclined, I will select one prisoner at random and escort him to the switch room. This prisoner will select one of the two switches and reverse its position. He must move one, but only one of the switches. He can't move both but he can't move none either. Then he'll be led back to his cell."
"No one else will enter the switch room until I lead the next prisoner there, and he'll be instructed to do the same thing. I'm going to choose prisoners at random. I may choose the same guy three times in a row, or I may jump around and come back."
"But, given enough time, everyone will eventually visit the switch room as many times as everyone else. At any time any one of you may declare to me, 'We have all visited the switch room.'
"If it is true, then you will all be set free. If it is false, and somebody has not yet visited the switch room, you will be fed to the alligators."
*note - the only difference from Scenario B, the original position of the 2 switches are known.
Hint:
Assuming that:
A) There is no restriction on the amount of time the prisoners could take before sending the notice to the warden that everyone has been to the switch room at least once.
B) There is no restriction on the number of time each prisoner can visit the switch room
C) The warden will not attempt any foul moves, such as intentionally not bringing a certain prisoner to the switch room forever.
Human Solution:
1.        Appoint a "scorekeeper" and the other 22 prisoners as "transmitters".
2.        When a transmitter enter the switch room for the first time, he will flick switch B ON if he sees it in the OFF position.  Alternatively, he will flick switch A if he sees switch B is in the ON position and waits for his next visit.  The transmitter's mission is to find ONE opportunity to flick switch B to the ON position.  After he completes his mission, he will flick switch A for all subsequent visits.  In short, each transmitter's role is to send a signal to the scorekeeper that he has been to the switch room.
3.        The scorekeeper's role is to flick off switch B whenever he sees it in the ON position.  Each time he flicks off switch B he adds 1 to his score.  When he sees switch B is already OFF, he flicks switch A instead and does not add to the score.  As soon as he accumulates 22, he reports to the Warden.
Response:
The problem asks for a strategy for 23 prisoners to determine when all of them have visited a switch room. One prisoner must make a declaration, and if it's true, all are freed; if false, all are doomed. The switch room has two switches, A and B, initially both OFF. Each prisoner visiting the room must flip exactly one switch.

Let N = 23 be the number of prisoners.
The strategy designates one prisoner as the "Counter" (let's call him P1) and the other N-1 prisoners as "Workers" (P2, ..., P23).

State variables:
1.  Switches: A and B, each can be ON or OFF. Initial state: A=OFF, B=OFF.
2.  Counter P1: An integer variable `count`, stored in P1's memory, initialized to 0. This variable tracks the number of distinct Worker prisoners P1 knows to have visited the switch room.
3.  Worker Pi (for i = 2 to N): A boolean variable `has_signaled`, stored in Pi's memory, initialized to `false`. This variable tracks whether Pi has successfully signaled their first visit.

The Strategy:

Part 1: Protocol for the Counter (P1)
When P1 enters the switch room:
1.  Examine switch A.
    a.  If switch A is ON:
        i.  Increment `count` by 1.
        ii. Turn switch A OFF.
    b.  If switch A is OFF:
        i.  Flip switch B (if B is ON, turn it OFF; if B is OFF, turn it ON).
2.  After performing the switch operation, check the value of `count`.
    a.  If `count` is equal to N-1 (which is 22 for N=23):
        i.  Declare to the warden: "We have all visited the switch room."

Part 2: Protocol for a Worker (Pi, where i is from 2 to N)
When Pi enters the switch room:
1.  Check their internal `has_signaled` variable.
    a.  If `has_signaled` is `false`:
        i.  Examine switch A.
            1.  If switch A is OFF:
                a.  Turn switch A ON.
                b.  Set `has_signaled` to `true`.
            2.  If switch A is ON: (This means another worker has signaled, but the Counter hasn't processed it yet. Pi must wait for a future turn to signal.)
                a.  Flip switch B.
    b.  If `has_signaled` is `true`: (Pi has already successfully signaled a visit.)
        i.  Flip switch B.

Formal Reasoning for Correctness:

Let V_k be the proposition that prisoner Pk has visited the switch room at least once. The declaration D ("We have all visited the switch room") is made by P1 when P1's `count` variable reaches N-1. We must prove that D implies (V_1 AND V_2 AND ... AND V_N).

1.  P1's Visit (V_1):
    The `count` variable is P1's internal counter. P1 can only increment `count` or make the declaration D when P1 is in the switch room. For `count` to reach N-1 (22), P1 must have visited the switch room at least N-1 times (each time P1 increments `count`, it's a distinct visit where P1 found switch A ON). Since N=23, N-1 = 22 >= 1. Therefore, if P1 makes the declaration D, V_1 is true.

2.  Workers' Visits (V_2, ..., V_N):
    a.  P1 increments `count` only when P1 finds switch A in the ON position. After incrementing `count`, P1 turns switch A OFF.
    b.  Switch A is turned ON only by a Worker prisoner Pi (i in {2, ..., N}) for whom `has_signaled` is `false` and who finds switch A in the OFF position.
    c.  When such a Worker Pi turns switch A ON, Pi immediately sets their `has_signaled` variable to `true`.
    d.  Once `has_signaled` is `true` for a Worker Pi, Pi will never again turn switch A ON. On any subsequent visits, Pi will only flip switch B (either because `has_signaled` is `true`, or because `has_signaled` is `false` but switch A was already ON).
    e.  Therefore, each time P1 finds switch A ON and increments `count`, this ON state must have been caused by a *unique* Worker prisoner Pi performing their signaling action for the first time.
    f.  For `count` to reach N-1, it means that N-1 distinct Worker prisoners must each have:
        i.  Entered the switch room.
        ii. Found switch A OFF and their `has_signaled` flag `false`.
        iii. Turned switch A ON.
        iv. Set their `has_signaled` flag to `true`.
    g.  This implies that all N-1 Worker prisoners (P2, ..., P_N) must have visited the switch room at least once to perform this signaling action. Thus, V_2, V_3, ..., V_N are all true.

3.  Conclusion of Correctness:
    From (1) and (2g), if P1 makes the declaration D (because `count` = N-1), then V_1 is true, and V_k is true for all k from 2 to N. Therefore, all N prisoners have visited the switch room. The declaration is true, and the prisoners will be freed.

Formal Reasoning for Liveness (the declaration will eventually be made):

The problem states: "given enough time, everyone will eventually visit the switch room as many times as everyone else." This is a strong fairness guarantee, implying every prisoner will be selected to visit the switch room infinitely often over an infinite time period.

1.  A Worker Pi needs to signal: Consider a Worker Pi for whom `has_signaled` is `false`. Pi needs to enter the switch room when switch A is OFF to be able to turn A ON and set `has_signaled` to `true`.
2.  Resetting switch A: If switch A is ON (because some Worker Pj set it ON), it will remain ON until P1 visits. The fairness guarantee ensures P1 will eventually visit. Upon visiting and finding A ON, P1 will increment `count` and turn switch A OFF.
3.  Opportunity to signal: Once switch A is OFF (either initially, or after P1 turns it OFF), it will remain OFF until a Worker Pi (with `has_signaled`=`false`) visits and turns it ON.
    - If P1 visits while A is OFF, P1 flips B, and A remains OFF.
    - If a Worker Pj (with `has_signaled`=`true`) visits while A is OFF, Pj flips B, and A remains OFF.
    - If a Worker Pk (with `has_signaled`=`false`) visits while A is OFF, Pk turns A ON and sets `has_signaled` to `true`.
4.  All Workers will signal: Due to the fairness guarantee, every Worker Pi with `has_signaled`=`false` will eventually be selected to visit the room. If A is ON when Pi visits, Pi flips B and waits for another turn. P1 will eventually turn A OFF. Then, Pi (or another unsignaled worker) will eventually visit when A is OFF. At this point, Pi can make their signal. This ensures that, eventually, every Worker Pi will set their `has_signaled` flag to `true`.
5.  Counter P1 will count all signals: Each time a Worker Pi sets A ON, P1 will eventually visit (by fairness), see A ON, increment `count`, and set A OFF. This will happen for signals from N-1 distinct Workers.
6.  Declaration: Therefore, `count` will eventually reach N-1. At this point, P1 will make the declaration.

The strategy ensures that every prisoner flips exactly one switch per visit, as required. The initial state (A=OFF, B=OFF) is correctly handled; P1 will initially find A OFF and flip B, and the first Worker to enter will find A OFF and be able to signal.

The strategy is sound and will lead to the prisoners' freedom.

Final answer: The prisoners should adopt the "Designated Counter" strategy described above. One prisoner is designated as the counter (P1). Switch A is used by other prisoners (P2-P23, "workers") to signal their first visit. Switch B is used to ensure a switch is always flipped.
- P1 (Counter): If A is ON, increment internal count, turn A OFF. If count is 22, declare all have visited. If A is OFF, flip B.
- Pi (Worker i=2 to 23): If this is Pi's first time successfully signaling (internal flag `has_signaled` is false) AND A is OFF, turn A ON and set `has_signaled` to true. Otherwise (if `has_signaled` is true OR A is already ON), flip B.

Question:
There is a ten-digit mystery number (no leading 0), represented by ABCDEFGHIJ, where each numeral, 0 through 9, is used once.  Given the following clues, what is the number?
1) A + B + C + D + E is a multiple of 6.
2) F + G + H + I + J is a multiple of 5.
3) A + C + E + G + I is a multiple of 9.
4) B + D + F + H + J is a multiple of 2.
5) AB is a multiple of 3.
6) CD is a multiple of 4.
7) EF is a multiple of 7.
8) GH is a multiple of 8.
9) IJ is a multiple of 10.
10) FE, HC, and JA are all prime numbers.
Hint: Notice that when combining clues 1 and 2, you have information about the sum of digits. You can do the same for clues 3 and 4.
Human Solution:
5736912480
A = 5, B = 7, C = 3, D = 6, E = 9, F = 1, G = 2, H = 4, I = 8, J = 0
1) 5 + 7 + 3 + 6 + 9 = 30, which is a multiple of 6.
2) 1 + 2 + 4 + 8 + 0 = 15, which is a multiple of 5.
3) 5 + 3 + 9 + 2 + 8 = 27, which is a multiple of 9.
4) 7 + 6 + 1 + 4 + 0 = 18, which is a multiple of 2.
5) 57 is a multiple of 3.
6) 36 is a multiple of 4.
7) 91 is a multiple of 7.
8) 24 is a multiple of 8.
9) 80 is a multiple of 10.
10) 19, 43, and 05 are prime numbers.
A) The sum of digits 0 through 9 is 45.  To satisfy Conditions 1 and 2, a pair of multiples must equal 45.  The only pair that satisfies those conditions are 30 (multiple of 6) and 15 (multiple of 5).  Likewise, to satisfy Conditions 3 and 4, the pair of multiples must be 27 (multiple of 9) and 18 (multiple of 2).
B) Make lists of the multiples of 3, 4, 7, 8, and 10 (for Conditions 5 through 9).  Delete multiples whose digits are the same (33, 44, 66, 77, 88, 99).
C) To satisfy Condition 9, J must be 0.  Delete multiples that require 0 in a different location.  For JA to be prime (Condition 10), A must be: 2, 3, 5, or 7.  Delete multiples of 3 that have another digit for A.
D) For FE and HC to be prime (Condition 10), C and E can not be even or 5.  Delete multiples of 4 and 7 that have another digit for C and E.
E) Per Condition 4, B + D + F + H + J = 18.  D, H, and J must be even (required to form multiples of even numbers).  To attain the sum of 18 (an even number), B and F must either be both odd or both even.  If both are even, then the sum of those five digits would be 20.  B and F must be odd.  Delete multiples of 3 and 7 that have an even digit for B and F.  The only remaining multiple of 7 is 91.  E is 9 and F is 1.  Delete multiples that require 1 or 9 in a different location.
F) The only remaining options for AB contain 7.  Delete multiples that require 7 in a different location.  The only remaining options for CD contain 3.  Delete multiples that require 3 in a different location.
G) To satisfy Condition 1, CD must be 36 and AB must be either 57 or 75.  C is 3 and D is 6.  Delete multiples that require 5, 6, or 7 in a different location.
H) The only remaining options for GH contain 4.  Delete multiples that require 4 in a different location.
I) Per Condition 3, A + C + E + G + I = 27.  Since C =3 and I = 9, the other three must total 15.  There is only one combination of remaining multiples (57, 24, and 80) that can satisfy this condition.  A is 5, G is 2, and I is 8.  B is 7 and H is 4.
Response:
Let the ten-digit number be ABCDEFGHIJ. Each numeral from 0 to 9 is used exactly once. A ≠ 0.

First, let's list the clues:
1) A + B + C + D + E ≡ 0 (mod 6)
2) F + G + H + I + J ≡ 0 (mod 5)
3) A + C + E + G + I ≡ 0 (mod 9)
4) B + D + F + H + J ≡ 0 (mod 2)
5) 10A + B ≡ 0 (mod 3)
6) 10C + D ≡ 0 (mod 4)
7) 10E + F ≡ 0 (mod 7)
8) 10G + H ≡ 0 (mod 8)
9) 10I + J ≡ 0 (mod 10)
10) 10F + E, 10H + C, and 10J + A are prime numbers.

Let S be the sum of all digits: S = 0+1+...+9 = 45.

From clue 9, 10I + J ≡ 0 (mod 10). This implies J must be 0.
Digits used: {J=0}. Remaining digits: {1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8,9}.

Let S1 = A+B+C+D+E and S2 = F+G+H+I+J.
S1 + S2 = S = 45.
From clue 1, S1 = 6k. From clue 2, S2 = 5m.
So 6k + 5m = 45.
Since 6k is a multiple of 6, 5m must be 45 - 6k. So 5m ≡ 45 (mod 6), which means 5m ≡ 3 (mod 6).
Let's test values for m:
m=1: 5m=5 ≡ 5 (mod 6)
m=2: 5m=10 ≡ 4 (mod 6)
m=3: 5m=15 ≡ 3 (mod 6). This is a possible value for S2.
m=4: 5m=20 ≡ 2 (mod 6)
m=5: 5m=25 ≡ 1 (mod 6)
m=6: 5m=30 ≡ 0 (mod 6)
The sum S2 = F+G+H+I+J must be positive. Max sum of 5 distinct digits including 0 is 9+8+7+6+0 = 30. Min sum is 1+2+3+4+0=10.
So S2 can be 15 or 30.
If S2 = 15, then S1 = 45 - 15 = 30. 30 is a multiple of 6. This works.
If S2 = 30, then S1 = 45 - 30 = 15. 15 is not a multiple of 6. This doesn't work.
So, we must have:
A + B + C + D + E = 30 (S1)
F + G + H + I + J = 15 (S2)
Since J=0, F + G + H + I = 15 (S2').

Let S3 = A+C+E+G+I and S4 = B+D+F+H+J.
S3 + S4 = S = 45.
From clue 3, S3 ≡ 0 (mod 9). Possible values for S3 (sum of 5 distinct digits, A≠0, J=0, I≠0):
Min sum for S3 (e.g. A=1,C=2,E=3,G=4,I=5, not considering J=0 yet): 1+2+3+4+5=15.
Max sum for S3 (e.g. A=9,C=8,E=7,G=6,I=5): 9+8+7+6+5=35.
So S3 can be 18, 27, or 36 (not possible, max is 35).
From clue 4, S4 ≡ 0 (mod 2) (i.e., S4 is even).
If S3 = 18, then S4 = 45 - 18 = 27 (odd). This doesn't work.
If S3 = 27, then S4 = 45 - 27 = 18 (even). This works.
So we must have:
A + C + E + G + I = 27 (S3)
B + D + F + H + J = 18 (S4)
Since J=0, B + D + F + H = 18 (S4').

From clue 10, JA is prime. Since J=0, JA represents the digit A. So A must be a prime digit.
A ∈ {2, 3, 5, 7}. (A≠0).

From clue 10, FE is prime. From clue 7, EF (10E+F) is a multiple of 7. E≠0, F≠0, E≠F.
Possible EF (multiple of 7): 14, 21, 28, 35, 42, 49, 56, 63, (07 not poss F!=0), (70 not poss E!=0), (77 not poss E!=F), 84, 91, 98.
Corresponding FE values: 41, 12, 82, 53, 24, 94, 65, 36, 48, 19, 89.
Primes among these FE values: 41, 53, 19, 89.
So (F,E) can be:
1. (F=4, E=1): EF=14, FE=41. Used digits {0,1,4}.
2. (F=5, E=3): EF=35, FE=53. Used digits {0,3,5}.
3. (F=1, E=9): EF=91, FE=19. Used digits {0,1,9}.
4. (F=8, E=9): EF=98, FE=89. Used digits {0,8,9}.

Let's analyze these cases for (F,E).

Case 1: (F,E) = (4,1). Digits used: J=0, E=1, F=4.
A ∈ {2,3,5,7}. A cannot be E or F. So A ∈ {2,3,5,7}.
S1: A+B+C+D+1 = 30  => A+B+C+D = 29.
S2': 4+G+H+I = 15     => G+H+I = 11.
S3: A+C+1+G+I = 27   => A+C+G+I = 26.
S4': B+D+4+H = 18     => B+D+H = 14.
Available digits for A,B,C,D,G,H,I are {2,3,5,6,7,8,9}.
   Subcase 1.1: A=2. From clue 5 (A+B ≡ 0 mod 3): 2+B ≡ 0 (mod 3). Possible B are 1 (used E), 4 (used F), 7. So B=7.
   Digits used: J=0, E=1, F=4, A=2, B=7. Remaining: {3,5,6,8,9}.
   A+B+C+D=29 => 2+7+C+D=29 => C+D=20.
   Max sum of two distinct digits from {3,5,6,8,9} is 9+8=17. C+D=20 is impossible. So A≠2.
   Subcase 1.2: A=3. 3+B ≡ 0 (mod 3). Possible B are 0 (used J), 6, 9. So B∈{6,9}.
   Digits used: J=0, E=1, F=4, A=3. Remaining: {2,5,6,7,8,9}.
   If B=6: Used {0,1,3,4,6}. Rem {2,5,7,8,9}. C+D=29-(3+6)=20. Max sum 9+8=17. Impossible.
   If B=9: Used {0,1,3,4,9}. Rem {2,5,6,7,8}. C+D=29-(3+9)=17. Max sum 8+7=15. Impossible. So A≠3.
   Subcase 1.3: A=5. 5+B ≡ 0 (mod 3) => 2+B ≡ 0 (mod 3). B∈{1 (used E), 4 (used F), 7}. So B=7.
   Digits used: J=0, E=1, F=4, A=5, B=7. Remaining: {2,3,6,8,9}.
   C+D=29-(5+7)=17. Possible (C,D) from {2,3,6,8,9} are (8,9) or (9,8).
   Clue 6 (CD is mult of 4): D must be even. So (C,D)=(9,8). CD=98. 98 is not mult of 4 (98/4 = 24.5). Impossible. So A≠5.
   Subcase 1.4: A=7. 7+B ≡ 0 (mod 3) => 1+B ≡ 0 (mod 3). B∈{2,5,8}. (B!=1,4).
   Digits used: J=0, E=1, F=4, A=7. Remaining: {2,3,5,6,8,9}.
   If B=2: Used {0,1,2,4,7}. Rem {3,5,6,8,9}. C+D=29-(7+2)=20. Max sum 9+8=17. Impossible.
   If B=5: Used {0,1,4,5,7}. Rem {2,3,6,8,9}. C+D=29-(7+5)=17. (C,D) is (8,9) or (9,8). D must be even. So (C,D)=(9,8). CD=98 (not mult of 4). Impossible.
   If B=8: Used {0,1,4,7,8}. Rem {2,3,5,6,9}. C+D=29-(7+8)=14. D must be even. D∈{2,6}.
      If D=2, C=12 (not digit).
      If D=6, C=8 (C cannot be B=8). Impossible. So A≠7.
Case 1 (F,E)=(4,1) yields no solutions.

Case 2: (F,E) = (5,3). Digits used: J=0, E=3, F=5.
A ∈ {2,3,5,7}. A cannot be E or F. So A ∈ {2,7}.
S1: A+B+C+D+3 = 30  => A+B+C+D = 27.
S2': 5+G+H+I = 15     => G+H+I = 10.
S3: A+C+3+G+I = 27   => A+C+G+I = 24.
S4': B+D+5+H = 18     => B+D+H = 13.
Available digits for A,B,C,D,G,H,I are {1,2,4,6,7,8,9}.
   Subcase 2.1: A=2. 2+B ≡ 0 (mod 3). B∈{1,4,7}. (B!=0,2,3,5).
   Digits used: J=0, E=3, F=5, A=2. Remaining: {1,4,6,7,8,9}.
   If B=1: Used {0,1,2,3,5}. Rem {4,6,7,8,9}. C+D=27-(2+1)=24. Max sum 9+8=17. Impossible.
   If B=4: Used {0,2,3,4,5}. Rem {1,6,7,8,9}. C+D=27-(2+4)=21. Max sum 9+8=17. Impossible.
   If B=7: Used {0,2,3,5,7}. Rem {1,4,6,8,9}. C+D=27-(2+7)=18. Pair from remaining is (9,9) if C=D allowed. Not allowed. Max sum 9+8=17. Impossible. So A≠2.
   Subcase 2.2: A=7. 7+B ≡ 0 (mod 3) => 1+B ≡ 0 (mod 3). B∈{2,8}. (B!=0,3,5,7).
   Digits used: J=0, E=3, F=5, A=7. Remaining: {1,2,4,6,8,9}.
   If B=2: Used {0,2,3,5,7}. Rem {1,4,6,8,9}. C+D=27-(7+2)=18. Max sum 9+8=17. Impossible.
   If B=8: Used {0,3,5,7,8}. Rem {1,2,4,6,9}. C+D=27-(7+8)=12. D must be even. D∈{2,4,6}.
      If D=2, C=10 (not digit).
      If D=4, C=8 (C cannot be B=8).
      If D=6, C=6 (not distinct).
      (Also, if C=9, D=3 (D cannot be E=3)).
   So A≠7.
Case 2 (F,E)=(5,3) yields no solutions.

Case 3: (F,E) = (1,9). Digits used: J=0, E=9, F=1.

S2': 1+G+H+I = 15     => G+H+I = 14.
S3: A+C+9+G+I = 27   => A+C+G+I = 18.

   Digits used: J=0,F=1,E=9,A=2. Rem {3,4,5,6,7,8}.
   If B=4: Used {0,1,2,4,9}. Rem {3,5,6,7,8}. C+D=21-(2+4)=15. D must be even. D∈{6,8}.

      If D=8, C=7. CD=78 (not mult of 4). Failed. So B≠4.

Question:
There is a ten-digit mystery number (no leading 0), represented by ABCDEFGHIJ, where each numeral, 0 through 9, is used once.  Given the following clues, what is the number?
1) Either A = B / 3 or A = G + 3.
2) Either B = I - 4 or B = E + 4.
3) Either C = J + 2 or C = F * 3.
4) Either D = G * 4 or D = E / 3.
5) Either E = J - 1 or E = D / 4.
6) Either F = B * 2 or F = A - 4.
7) Either G = F + 1 or G = I - 3.
8) Either H = A / 2 or H = C * 3.
9) Either I = H + 3 or I = D / 2.
10) Either J = H - 2 or J = C * 2.
Hint: Check each letter for any value that it can not be on the left side of an equation.  For example, A can not be 0, as B would also have to be 0 or G would have to be negative.
Human Solution:
5038612947
A = 5, B = 0, C = 3, D = 8, E = 6, F = 1, G = 2, H = 9, I = 4, J = 7
1) A = G + 3 = 2 + 3 = 5.
2) B = I - 4 = 4 - 4 = 0.
3) C = F * 3 = 1 * 3 = 3.
4) D = G * 4 = 2 * 4 = 8.
5) E = J - 1 = 7 - 1 = 6.
6) F = A - 4 = 5 - 4 = 1.
7) G = F + 1 = 1 + 1 = 2.
8) H = C * 3 = 3 * 3 = 9.
9) I = D / 2 = 8 / 2 = 4.
10) J = H - 2 = 9 - 2 = 7.
A) Check each letter for any value that it can not be on the left side of an equation.  For example, A can not be 0, as B would also have to be 0 or G would have to be negative.  On the first pass through the letters, the following can be determined: A not 0, C not 0, C not 1, D not 0, D not 5, D not 6, D not 7, D not 9, E not 9, F not 7, F not 9, G not 8 (because F not 7), H not 0, H not 5, H not 7, H not 8, I not 0, I not 3 (because H not 0 and D not 6), I not 8 (because H not 5), J not 3 (because H not 5), J not 5 (because H not 7), and J not 9.
B) Make a second pass through the letters.  The following can be determined: C not 5, C not 7, D not 3, E not 4, E not 8, and G not 0.
C) Make a third pass.  The following can be determined: B not 8.
D) For D, only four numbers are still valid: 1, 2, 4, and 8.  Plug each of these numbers into D and check the resulting flow of equations.  If D = 1, then the resulting flow will lead to J having to be both 4 and 0.  If D = 2, then the resulting flow will lead to 2 also being assigned to G.  If D = 4, then the resulting flow will lead to 4 also being assigned to either A or I.  If D = 8, then G = 2, F = 1, and A = 5.
E) For E, four numbers are still valid: 0, 3, 6, and 7.  Plug each number into E and check the resulting flow. Question:
Typical "stars" are drawn in connected, but not repeated, line segments. For example, a 5-point star is drawn as such - line segments AC, CE, EB, BD, DA. The segments must always alternate a constant number of points (in the above case, skipping 1 point in between).
Given the information that there is only 1 way to draw a 5-point star, and that there is NO way to draw a 6-point star (in continuous lines, that is), and there are 2 ways to draw a 7-point star, how many different ways are there to draw a 1000-point star?
Hint: It's not guess work. Think of factors and mirror images.  Try drawing out examples.
Human Solution:
199.
First, let's examine the 5-point star and why there is only that one, described, way to draw it. Starting at A, you cannot go straight to point B, otherwise you will have a pentagon, not a star. Same with point E. AC and AD (and their progressions) yield identical pictures (notice that the last segment in the AC one is DA, literally reverse all the letters to get AD ending in CA).
Now, for a 6-point star, there are points A, B, C, D, E, and F. Starting at A, we cannot go to B or F, because then we have a hexagon. If we go AC, then we must go CE, then CA... making a triangle, not a 6-point star. Going backwards, AE, EC, EA; mirror image. If we skip 2 points, we go AD, then DA, a straight line, hardly a 6-point star.
For a 7-point star, A-G, AB and AG are not possible, as that's a heptagon. AC, CE, EG, GB, BD, DF, FA is one way to draw the star, skipping one point in between. Also, AD, DG, GC, CF, FB, BE, EA, skipping two points in between each, is the other way. The last two line possibilities, AF and AE are mirror images of the two working scenarios.
Examining the above information a little more deeply, we see that we must divide all possible drawings by two, to get rid of the mirror images. Also, we cannot use the point immediately to the left, that is AB as a segment. This explains why there is only 1 way for a 5-point, and 2 for a 7-point, but does not explain the 6-point. Of those remaining points (dealing only with the first half, again, mirror images), those that are factors of the number of total points do not work, because you will end up back at the starting point before hitting every number. AC is a factor in six because it passes point B, so it's 2. AD is a factor of 3 (B, C and D). Not only factors, but multiples of factors, as well (for example, skipping 4 points in the 6-point still does not work).
Using the knowledge of mirrors, first point impossibility (AB) and factors, we see that the number 1000 is made up of 10^3, or 2^3*5^3. Without going through every factor, it's quickly and easily discernible that of the numbers 1-1000, 2 or multiples of it encompass 500 numbers, all evens. Any multiple of 5 includes 200 numbers, half of which end in 0 and are already included with the 2's, so there are 600 unique factors and multiples between 1 and 1000. That leaves us with 400 that are *not*, which should explain how many unique stars we can make. Remember to cut it in half because of mirroring, leaving us with 200, and to discount the AB segment (factor of 1), leaving us with 199. (If you discount AB, and THEN halve it, remember you needed to remove A[Z], the mirror image of that point).
Response:
Let $N$ be the number of points on a circle. Let the points be $P_0, P_1, \ldots, P_{N-1}$ in clockwise order.
A star is drawn by choosing a starting point, say $P_0$, and then connecting it to $P_k$ for some integer $k$. Then from $P_k$, connecting to $P_{2k \pmod N}$, and so on. The sequence of points visited is $P_0, P_k, P_{2k \pmod N}, P_{3k \pmod N}, \ldots$.

The problem states "stars are drawn in connected, but not repeated, line segments".
1.  "Connected": The sequence of points $P_0, P_k, P_{2k \pmod N}, \ldots, P_{(N-1)k \pmod N}$ must visit all $N$ points before returning to $P_0$. This is equivalent to the condition that the set $\{0, k \pmod N, 2k \pmod N, \ldots, (N-1)k \pmod N\}$ is equal to the set $\{0, 1, \ldots, N-1\}$. This holds if and only if $\gcd(k, N) = 1$. If $\gcd(k,N)=d>1$, the process would generate $d$ separate polygons, each of $N/d$ vertices. The problem's example for $N=6$ ("NO way to draw a 6-point star (in continuous lines, that is)") supports this: for $N=6$, if one chose $k=2$, it would result in two disjoint triangles ($P_0P_2P_4$ and $P_1P_3P_5$). This is not a "continuous line" star. Thus, $\gcd(k,N)=1$ is a necessary condition.

2.  "Not repeated line segments": The drawing process generates $N$ line segments: $(P_0, P_k)$, $(P_k, P_{2k})$, ..., $(P_{(N-1)k}, P_0)$. For $N>2$, if $\gcd(k,N)=1$, these $N$ segments will be distinct as undirected edges. (If an edge $\{P_a,P_{a+k}\}$ was the same as $\{P_b,P_{b+k}\}$ for $a \ne b$, it would imply $P_a=P_{b+k}$ and $P_{a+k}=P_b$. This leads to $2k \equiv 0 \pmod N$. If $\gcd(k,N)=1$, $N$ must divide 2, so $N=2$. For $N>2$, this cannot happen.)

3.  "The segments must always alternate a constant number of points": This means $k$ is constant throughout the drawing. The problem states "skipping 1 point in between" for the 5-point star. If $s$ is the number of points skipped, the step $k$ is $s+1$. So $k \ge 1$.

4.  Distinction between stars and polygons:
    For $N=5$, there is 1 way. The values of $k$ such that $\gcd(k,5)=1$ are $k=1,2,3,4$.
    If $k=1$ (0 points skipped), the segments are $(P_0,P_1), (P_1,P_2), \ldots$. This forms a regular pentagon.
    If $k=4$ (3 points skipped, or $k=5-1$), the segments are $(P_0,P_4), (P_4,P_3), \ldots$. This is also a regular pentagon (drawn in reverse direction or seen as connecting to the point $P_{-1}$).
    The problem's example for $N=5$ is "AC, CE, EB, BD, DA". If A is $P_0$, B is $P_1$, etc., this means $P_0P_2, P_2P_4, P_4P_1, P_1P_3, P_3P_0$. This corresponds to $k=2$ (skipping $s=1$ point).
    The problem implies that regular polygons ($k=1$ or $k=N-1$) are not considered "stars". So we must exclude $k=1$ and $k=N-1$.
    The set of $k$ values that can generate stars are those $k \in \{2, 3, \ldots, N-2\}$ such that $\gcd(k,N)=1$.

5.  What constitutes a "different way" to draw a star:
    For $N=5$, the $k$ values that are not polygons are $k=2$ and $k=3$.
    The star drawn with $k=2$ is $P_0P_2P_4P_1P_3P_0$. The set of edges is $\{\{P_0,P_2\}, \{P_2,P_4\}, \{P_4,P_1\}, \{P_1,P_3\}, \{P_3,P_0\}\}$.
    The star drawn with $k=3$ is $P_0P_3P_1P_4P_2P_0$. The set of edges is $\{\{P_0,P_3\}, \{P_3,P_1\}, \{P_1,P_4\}, \{P_4,P_2\}, \{P_2,P_0\}\}$.
    As shown in thought process, these two sets of edges are identical (e.g. $\{P_0,P_2\}$ is the same edge as $\{P_2,P_0\}$).
    Since there is only 1 way to draw a 5-point star, $k=2$ and $k=3$ must be considered the same way.
    In general, choosing $k$ results in the same geometric star shape as choosing $N-k$.
    So, the number of distinct stars is half the count of $k$ values in step 4.

Combining these conditions:
The number of integers $k$ such that $1 \le k < N$ and $\gcd(k,N)=1$ is given by Euler's totient function, $\phi(N)$.
We exclude $k=1$ and $k=N-1$. So we have $\phi(N)-2$ such values of $k$. (This assumes $N>2$, so $1 \ne N-1$ and $\phi(N) \ge 2$).
Since $k$ and $N-k$ produce the same star shape, we divide by 2. Note that $k = N-k$ implies $N=2k$. Since $\gcd(k,N)=1$, $k$ must be 1 and $N=2$. We are excluding $k=1$, so $k \ne N-k$ for any $k$ we consider for stars for $N>2$.
The number of ways to draw an $N$-point star is $(\phi(N)-2)/2$.

Let's test this formula with the given examples:
-   For $N=5$: $\phi(5) = 5-1 = 4$. Number of ways = $(\phi(5)-2)/2 = (4-2)/2 = 1$. This matches the problem statement.
-   For $N=6$: $\phi(6) = 6(1-1/2)(1-1/3) = 2$. Number of ways = $(\phi(6)-2)/2 = (2-2)/2 = 0$. This matches the problem statement. (The $k$ values are $1,5$, both excluded).
-   For $N=7$: $\phi(7) = 7-1 = 6$. Number of ways = $(\phi(7)-2)/2 = (6-2)/2 = 2$. This matches the problem statement. (The $k$ values are $1,2,3,4,5,6$. Exclude $1,6$. Remaining are $2,3,4,5$. $k=2$ is paired with $k=5$. $k=3$ is paired with $k=4$. These are the 2 ways).

The formula is consistent with all information given.
Now we apply this formula for $N=1000$.
First, calculate $\phi(1000)$.
$1000 = 10^3 = (2 \cdot 5)^3 = 2^3 \cdot 5^3$.
$\phi(1000) = \phi(2^3 \cdot 5^3) = \phi(2^3) \cdot \phi(5^3)$ (since $\phi$ is a multiplicative function).
$\phi(p^a) = p^a - p^{a-1}$.
$\phi(2^3) = 2^3 - 2^2 = 8 - 4 = 4$.
$\phi(5^3) = 5^3 - 5^2 = 125 - 25 = 100$.
So, $\phi(1000) = 4 \cdot 100 = 400$.

The number of ways to draw a 1000-point star is $(\phi(1000)-2)/2$.
Number of ways = $(400-2)/2 = 398/2 = 199$.
This formula counts the number of $k$ such that $\gcd(k,N)=1$ and $1 < k < N/2$.

Final check:
The number of points $N=1000$.
Number of integers $k$ such that $\gcd(k, 1000)=1$ and $1 \le k \le 999$ is $\phi(1000)=400$.
These $k$ values are symmetric around $N/2=500$. Since $\gcd(500,1000)=500 \ne 1$, $k=500$ is not among these 400 values.
So, there are $\phi(1000)/2 = 400/2 = 200$ values of $k$ such that $\gcd(k,1000)=1$ and $1 \le k < 500$.
These are the choices of $k$ that generate distinct stars, by convention taking the smaller of $k$ and $N-k$.
This count includes $k=1$. The star $\{N/1\}$ is the regular $N$-gon.
We exclude $k=1$ as it's a polygon, not a "star" in the typical sense (as implied by the problem's examples).
So the number of ways is $200 - 1 = 199$.
This confirms the formula $(\phi(N)-2)/2$.

Final answer is 199.

Final Answer: The number of ways to draw an $N$-point star according to the problem's definition is given by the formula $(\phi(N)-2)/2$.
First, we calculate $\phi(1000)$. The prime factorization of $1000$ is $2^3 \cdot 5^3$.
The Euler's totient function $\phi(N)$ is calculated as $N \prod_{p|N, p \text{ is prime}} (1 - 1/p)$.
So, $\phi(1000) = 1000 (1 - 1/2) (1 - 1/5) = 1000 (1/2) (4/5) = 1000 \cdot (2/5) = 400$.
Alternatively, using the formula $\phi(p^a) = p^a - p^{a-1}$:
$\phi(2^3) = 2^3 - 2^2 = 8 - 4 = 4$.
$\phi(5^3) = 5^3 - 5^2 = 125 - 25 = 100$.
Since $\phi$ is a multiplicative function, $\phi(1000) = \phi(2^3) \phi(5^3) = 4 \cdot 100 = 400$.
Using the derived formula, the number of ways to draw a 1000-point star is $(\phi(1000)-2)/2 = (400-2)/2 = 398/2 = 199$.

The final answer is $\boxed{199}$

Question:
I was playing a game of five card draw poker with a bunch of logicians.  By the time we had finished bidding and were just about to reveal our cards, I was pretty confident I would win of the four of us remaining.  I had three nines, some face card (I can't remember what suit or even whether it was a jack, queen, or king) and a four. (Or was it a five?  I can't remember.)
I was even more sure when two of my opponents laid down their cards.  One had a pair of fours and a pair of sevens, the other had a pair of twos and a pair of eights.  My third opponent, however, laid down his five cards face down in a row.  He said, "I have a straight, and the cards are, from lowest to highest: a ten, a jack, a queen, a king, and an ace.  I have at least one card of each of the four suits: clubs, spades, hearts, and diamonds.  I am fairly certain that this is the winning hand, but I'm feeling generous today, and I will give a third of the pot to whoever can determine which suit I have two cards of.
Now I know you can't figure it out without some clues.  Here they are:
1. The king is next to at least one diamond.
2. The queen is next to exactly one heart.
3. The jack is next to at least one spade, but is not next to any hearts.
4. The ten is next to at least one club.
5. The ace does not border any black cards, nor does it border any diamonds.
6. My two cards of the same suit are not next to each other.
7. Of the ten possible pairings of cards, only one pair, when removed, leaves three cards in ascending order from left to right.
8. My ace is not the card on the far left."
There was a minute's silence.  One of the other logicians said, "I give up!  There's no way to figure that out!"
The other agreed.  But I didn't.  I had just figured out which suit he had two of.
Which suit is it?
Hint:
The first step is to determine where the ace goes.
Also, consider this: How could I have figured it out when two expert logicians couldn't?
Human Solution:
The two cards on the ends and the card in the middle border a combined number of two suits.  So at least one pair of them should be listed as bordering a card of the same suit in clues 1-5.  Of the five, only the ace and the queen meet this criterion, so they must be two cards apart.  One of them must be in the center, but it can't be the ace (the two cards on the ends would only border hearts - and one of them has to be bordering something else from clues 1-4), so it must be the queen.  The ace is not on the left end from clue 8, so it must be on the right end, and the card next to it must be a heart.  So far we have this(X represents unknown):
X X Q X A
X X X H X
At least one of the two cards to the left of the queen is lower than the queen (two of the remaining cards are lower, and only one can be right of the queen), so the triplet that is in ascending order is the queen, the ace, and the single card to the left of the queen that is lower than the queen.  That means the king is left of the queen, and is also left of both the jack and the ten (otherwise, jack king ace or ten king ace would be a second triplet), so it must be on the far left.  The jack must be left of the ten (or else ten jack ace would be a second triplet), so it must be second from the left, and the ten must be second from the right.  The only card next to the king is the jack of diamonds (it's a diamond from clue 1).  So far we have(T is ten):
K J Q T A
X D X H X
Now we seem to be stuck.  We don't have any more clues that can be used.  So how did I figure it out?
I held a face card (I said so myself in the intro).  I must have known it cannot be that card and deduced the correct answer from there.
But which card did I have?  We already know the suit of the jack, so my holding a jack would not help.  Could I have held a queen?  No, because I know the queen to either be a spade or club (clue 6), so one of the cards next to the queen would have its clue satisfied (see clues 3 and 4), and I could not determine the suit of the card on the other side of it.
Therefore, I must have held a king.  But which king?  I know the king is not a diamond (clue 6) or a heart (clue 3).  If I held the king of clubs, then the king next to the jack would have satisfied the jack's clue, and I could not have determine the suit of either card next to the ten.
Therefore, I held the king of spades.  The king of clubs must have been on the far left (only suit available), so the only card next to the jack that could be a spade is the queen, so the only card next to the ten that could be a club is the ace.  In summary:
K J Q T A
C D S H C
Therefore there are two CLUBS.
Response:
Let the cards be represented by their values: T (Ten), J (Jack), Q (Queen), K (King), A (Ace). Let their numerical values be T=10, J=11, Q=12, K=13, A=14.
Let the five cards in the row, from left to right, be $X_1, X_2, X_3, X_4, X_5$. These are a permutation of {T,J,Q,K,A}.
Let $s(C)$ denote the suit of card $C$. The suits are Clubs (C), Spades (S), Hearts (H), Diamonds (D).
The problem states that there is at least one card of each suit. Since there are 5 cards, exactly one suit is repeated. We need to find this repeated suit.

Let's analyze the clues:

Clue 7: "Of the ten possible pairings of cards, only one pair, when removed, leaves three cards in ascending order from left to right."
This means we must find a permutation $(X_1,X_2,X_3,X_4,X_5)$ of (T,J,Q,K,A) such that exactly one of the 10 choices of $(X_i,X_j,X_k)$ (where the indices $i,j,k$ are preserved from the original sequence after removing two cards) satisfies $Value(X_i) < Value(X_j) < Value(X_k)$.
Let's test the permutation $(K,J,Q,T,A)$. Values: $(13,11,12,10,14)$.
The 10 sets of 3 cards are:
1.  Removing $X_1,X_2$ (K,J) leaves $(X_3,X_4,X_5) = (Q,T,A) = (12,10,14)$. Not ascending (12>10).
2.  Removing $X_1,X_3$ (K,Q) leaves $(X_2,X_4,X_5) = (J,T,A) = (11,10,14)$. Not ascending (11>10).
3.  Removing $X_1,X_4$ (K,T) leaves $(X_2,X_3,X_5) = (J,Q,A) = (11,12,14)$. Ascending. This is one success.
4.  Removing $X_1,X_5$ (K,A) leaves $(X_2,X_3,X_4) = (J,Q,T) = (11,12,10)$. Not ascending (12>10).
5.  Removing $X_2,X_3$ (J,Q) leaves $(X_1,X_4,X_5) = (K,T,A) = (13,10,14)$. Not ascending (13>10).
6.  Removing $X_2,X_4$ (J,T) leaves $(X_1,X_3,X_5) = (K,Q,A) = (13,12,14)$. Not ascending (13>12).
7.  Removing $X_2,X_5$ (J,A) leaves $(X_1,X_3,X_4) = (K,Q,T) = (13,12,10)$. Not ascending (13>12).
8.  Removing $X_3,X_4$ (Q,T) leaves $(X_1,X_2,X_5) = (K,J,A) = (13,11,14)$. Not ascending (13>11).
9.  Removing $X_3,X_5$ (Q,A) leaves $(X_1,X_2,X_4) = (K,J,T) = (13,11,10)$. Not ascending (13>11).
10. Removing $X_4,X_5$ (T,A) leaves $(X_1,X_2,X_3) = (K,J,Q) = (13,11,12)$. Not ascending (13>11).
This permutation $(K,J,Q,T,A)$ satisfies Clue 7.

Clue 8: "My ace is not the card on the far left."
The far left card is $X_1$. Here $X_5=A$. So $Pos(A)=5$. This means $A$ is on the far right, which is not the far left. Clue 8 is satisfied.
So the order of cards is $(K,J,Q,T,A)$.

Now let's determine the suits using the other clues.
$X_1=K, X_2=J, X_3=Q, X_4=T, X_5=A$.

Clue 5: "The ace does not border any black cards, nor does it border any diamonds."
The Ace ($A=X_5$) has only one neighbor, $X_4=T$. So the suit of $X_4=T$ must be Hearts. $s(T)=H$.

Clue 6: "My two cards of the same suit are not next to each other."
Since $s(T)=H$: $s(Q) \neq H$ (as $Q=X_3$ is neighbor of $T=X_4$) and $s(A) \neq H$ (as $A=X_5$ is neighbor of $T=X_4$).

Clue 1: "The king is next to at least one diamond."
The King ($K=X_1$) has only one neighbor, $X_2=J$. So $s(J)=D$.
From Clue 6, $s(K) \neq D$ and $s(Q) \neq D$ (as $Q=X_3$ is neighbor of $J=X_2$).

Clue 2: "The queen is next to exactly one heart."
The Queen ($Q=X_3$) has neighbors $X_2=J$ and $X_4=T$.
We know $s(T)=H$. So $T$ is a Heart neighbor.
Thus, the other neighbor $J$ must not be a Heart. $s(J) \neq H$. This is true, as $s(J)=D$. This clue is satisfied.

Clue 3: "The jack is next to at least one spade, but is not next to any hearts."
The Jack ($J=X_2$) has neighbors $X_1=K$ and $X_3=Q$.
So $s(K) \neq H$ and $s(Q) \neq H$. We already knew $s(Q) \neq H$ from $s(T)=H$ and Clue 6.
The condition "next to at least one spade" means $s(K)=S$ or $s(Q)=S$.

Clue 4: "The ten is next to at least one club."
The Ten ($T=X_4$) has neighbors $X_3=Q$ and $X_5=A$.
So $s(Q)=C$ or $s(A)=C$.

Summary of suit information:
1.  $s(T)=H$ (from Clue 5)
2.  $s(A) \neq H$ (from Clue 6, using $s(T)=H$)
3.  $s(Q) \neq H$ (from Clue 6, using $s(T)=H$)
4.  $s(J)=D$ (from Clue 1)
5.  $s(K) \neq D$ (from Clue 6, using $s(J)=D$)
6.  $s(Q) \neq D$ (from Clue 6, using $s(J)=D$)
7.  $s(K) \neq H$ (from Clue 3, using $s(J)=D$)
8.  ($s(K)=S$ or $s(Q)=S$) (from Clue 3)
9.  ($s(Q)=C$ or $s(A)=C$) (from Clue 4)

Let's consolidate:
-   $s(T)=H$
-   $s(J)=D$
-   $s(Q)$ can't be H (from 3), can't be D (from 6). So $s(Q)$ must be C or S.
-   $s(K)$ can't be D (from 5), can't be H (from 7). So $s(K)$ must be C or S.
-   $s(A)$ can't be H (from 2). So $s(A)$ must be C, S, or D.

From Clue 3 ($s(K)=S$ or $s(Q)=S$):
Case 1: $s(Q)=S$.
    Then $s(K)$ must be C (since $s(K) \in \{C,S\}$).
    From Clue 4 ($s(Q)=C$ or $s(A)=C$): Since $s(Q)=S \neq C$, it must be that $s(A)=C$.
    So far: $s(K)=C, s(J)=D, s(Q)=S, s(T)=H, s(A)=C$.
    The suits are {C, D, S, H, C}. All four suits are present (C,D,S,H). The repeated suit is Clubs (C).
    Let's check Clue 6 with $S_{rep}=C$: $s(K)=C$ and $s(A)=C$. $K=X_1$ and $A=X_5$. They are not adjacent. This is fine.
    This set of suit assignments satisfies all derived conditions. Let's perform a final check on all original clues with card order $(K,J,Q,T,A)$ and suits $(C,D,S,H,C)$:
    1.  K next to D: $N(K)=\{J\}$. $s(J)=D$. Yes.
    2.  Q next to exactly one H: $N(Q)=\{J,T\}$. $s(J)=D, s(T)=H$. Yes, T is H.
    3.  J next to S, not H: $N(J)=\{K,Q\}$. $s(K)=C, s(Q)=S$. One neighbor $Q$ is S. Neither $s(K)$ nor $s(Q)$ is H. Yes.
    4.  T next to C: $N(T)=\{Q,A\}$. $s(Q)=S, s(A)=C$. One neighbor $A$ is C. Yes.
    5.  A not border black/diamond: $N(A)=\{T\}$. $s(T)=H$. H is not black (C/S) and not D. Yes.
    6.  Repeated suit (C) not adjacent: $s(K)=C, s(A)=C$. $K=X_1, A=X_5$. Not adjacent. Yes.
    7.  Permutation $(K,J,Q,T,A)$ has one success. Yes.
    8.  Ace not far left: $A=X_5$. Yes.
    This is a consistent solution. The repeated suit is Clubs.

Case 2: $s(Q) \neq S$.
    Then from Clue 3 ($s(K)=S$ or $s(Q)=S$), it must be $s(K)=S$.
    Since $s(Q) \in \{C,S\}$, and $s(Q) \neq S$, then $s(Q)=C$.
    From Clue 4 ($s(Q)=C$ or $s(A)=C$): $s(Q)=C$ satisfies this. $s(A)$ is not forced to be C by this part.
    So far: $s(K)=S, s(J)=D, s(Q)=C, s(T)=H$.
    $s(A)$ must be C, S, or D.
    The suits are {S, D, C, H, $s(A)$}. All four suits are present. The repeated suit must be $s(A)$.
    So $s(A)$ must be one of S, D, C, H. But $s(A) \neq H$. So $s(A) \in \{S,D,C\}$.
    If $s(A)=S$: $S_{rep}=S$. Suits $(S,D,C,H,S)$. $s(K)=S, s(A)=S$. $K=X_1, A=X_5$. Not adjacent. This is fine by Clue 6.
        Check this assignment for $(K,J,Q,T,A)$ and suits $(S,D,C,H,S)$:
        1.  K next to D: $s(J)=D$. Yes.
        2.  Q next to one H: $N(Q)=\{J,T\}$. $s(J)=D, s(T)=H$. Yes.
        3.  J next to S, not H: $N(J)=\{K,Q\}$. $s(K)=S, s(Q)=C$. $K$ is S. $s(K),s(Q)$ are not H. Yes.
        4.  T next to C: $N(T)=\{Q,A\}$. $s(Q)=C, s(A)=S$. $Q$ is C. Yes.
        5.  A not border black/diamond: $N(A)=\{T\}$. $s(T)=H$. Yes.
        6.  Repeated suit (S) not adjacent: $s(K)=S, s(A)=S$. Not adjacent. Yes.
        All clues satisfied. The repeated suit is Spades.

Question:
Five friends spend every Monday night eating Chinese food from the Golden Dragon. Howard has Mu Shu Pork, Leonard has Spicy Szechuan Tofu, Penny has Shrimp with Lobster Sauce, Raj has Beef with String Beans, and Sheldon has Chicken and Broccoli: diced, not shredded, with brown rice, not white, low-sodium soy sauce and the good hot mustard from the Korean grocery.
After dinner, they play a role-playing game called World of Nerds.
In this game, each player takes on a character belonging to a different race of creature, has a different occupation, uses a different sort of weapon, specializes in fighting a particular kind of monster, and has a different skill level.
Can you determine the characteristics of each player's character from the following clues before someone sits in Sheldon's spot?
Players: Howard, Leonard, Penny, Raj and Sheldon
Races: elf, gremlin, halfling, hobbit and ogre
Occupations: archbishop, merchant, paladin, sorcerer and thief
Weapons: bolo, crossbow, dagger, fireballs and mace
Monsters: chimeras, giants, harpies, kobolds and orcs
Skill levels: range from 10-32
Clues:
1. The five characters in the game are Penny's, the 24th-level ogre, the thief, the fireball user, and the one skilled at fighting orcs.
2. The paladin isn't an elf.
3. The bolo user has a skill level twice that of the halfling.
4. Raj's character has a skill level eight levels higher than the paladin, who in turn is eight levels higher than the crossbow user.
5. The hobbit is no good at fighting giants.
6. The elf (who doesn't care for crossbows) is ten levels higher than the one who fights kobolds.
7. The one who is adept at fighting chimeras is four levels higher than Leonard's character (who isn't the archbishop).
8. The character at the lowest level (who isn't Penny) is at level ten and uses a dagger.
9. Neither the archbishop nor the merchant belongs to the race of gremlins.
10. The giant fighter never uses a mace in battle.
11. Raj's character isn't the elf.
12. Penny's character doesn't use the crossbow.
13. Howard's character is not particularly adept at fighting harpies.
Hint: Start by determining the 5 skill levels.
Human Solution:
Howard is the halfling and a level 10 thief who fights kobolds with a dagger.
Leonard is the hobbit and a level 16 merchant who fights orcs with a crossbow.
Penny is the elf and a level 20 archbishop who fights chimeras with a bolo.
Raj is the gremlin and a level 32 sorcerer who fights giants with fireballs.
Sheldon is the ogre and a level 24 paladin who fights harpies with a mace.
Explanation:
The first step is to determine the actual skill levels of the five players.
The lowest level is 10, held by the character using a dagger (clue 8).
From (4), the character using a crossbow has an unknown level, let's call it x; the paladin has x+8 and Raj has x+16. Note that x must be greater than 10 and less than or equal to 16, or else x+16 would be greater than 32.
The elf is none of these four players (2, 11, 6), but has a skill level of 10 more than one of them (6). This could be 20, x+10 or x+18.
One skill level has to be 24 (1), two skill levels must have a difference of 4 (7) and one skill level must be twice another (3).
If x=11, then the skill levels are 10, 11, 19, 27 and the elf's is either 20, 21 or 29. None of these is 24; therefore, x isn't 11. Similarly x isn't 12, 13 or 15.
If x=14, then the skill levels are 10, 14, 22, 30 and the elf's is either 20, 24 or 32. This provides a skill level of 24, but for the elf, instead of the ogre; therefore, x isn't 14.
Therefore, x=16 and the skill levels are 10 [dagger], 16 [crossbow], 24 [paladin=ogre], and 32 [Raj]. The elf's skill level must be 20, not 26, in order to satisfy clue (7). This means the elf fights chimeras and Leonard's character uses the crossbow.
Now that we know the skill levels, we can start building a list of the players, starting with the first clue:
Player 1 = Penny
Player 2 = ogre, level 24, paladin
Player 3 = thief
Player 4 = fireballs
Player 5 = orcs
Since the elf has a skill level of 20, the kobold fighter is level 10 (6), and uses the dagger (8). Penny's character doesn't use the dagger (8), and neither does the ogre, who is level 24. Therefore the thief does:
Player 1 = Penny
Player 2 = ogre, level 24, paladin
Player 3 = level 10, thief, kobolds, dagger
Player 4 = fireballs
Player 5 = orcs
Neither Penny's character (12) nor the ogre (4) uses the crossbow [Leonard], so the orc fighter must:
Player 1 = Penny
Player 2 = ogre, level 24, paladin
Player 3 = level 10, thief, kobolds, dagger
Player 4 = fireballs
Player 5 = Leonard, level 16, orcs, crossbow
The ogre can't use the bolo, as no one has level 12 (3), so Penny's character uses the bolo and the thief is the halfling. This leaves the ogre using the mace:
Player 1 = Penny, bolo
Player 2 = ogre, level 24, paladin, mace
Player 3 = halfing, level 10, thief, kobolds, dagger
Player 4 = fireballs
Player 5 = Leonard, level 16, orcs, crossbow
This means that Raj's character, at level 32, must use fireballs, and Penny's character must be the level 20 elf who fights chimeras:
Player 1 = Penny, elf, level 20, chimeras, bolo
Player 2 = ogre, level 24, paladin, mace
Player 3 = halfing, level 10, thief, kobolds, dagger
Player 4 = Raj, level 32, fireballs
Player 5 = Leonard, level 16, orcs, crossbow
The ogre, who uses a mace, doesn't fight giants (10); therefore the ogre fights harpies, leaving Raj's character as the giant fighter:
Player 1 = Penny, elf, level 20, chimeras, bolo
Player 2 = ogre, level 24, paladin, harpies, mace
Player 3 = halfing, level 10, thief, kobolds, dagger
Player 4 = Raj, level 32, giants, fireballs
Player 5 = Leonard, level 16, orcs, crossbow
The hobbit doesn't fight giants (5), so the hobbit must fight orcs, leaving Raj as the gremlin. The gremlin isn't the archbishop or the merchant, and so the gremlin is the sorcerer:
Player 1 = Penny, elf, level 20, chimeras, bolo
Player 2 = ogre, level 24, paladin, harpies, mace
Player 3 = halfing, level 10, thief, kobolds, dagger
Player 4 = Raj, gremlin, level 32, sorcerer, giants, fireballs
Player 5 = Leonard, hobbit, level 16, orcs, crossbow
Leonard's character must be the merchant, rather than the archbishop (7), leaving Penny's character as the archbishop:
Player 1 = Penny, elf, level 20, archbishop, chimeras, bolo
Player 2 = ogre, level 24, paladin, harpies, mace
Player 3 = halfing, level 10, thief, kobolds, dagger
Player 4 = Raj, gremlin, level 32, sorcerer, giants, fireballs
Player 5 = Leonard, hobbit, level 16, merchant, orcs, crossbow
Howard's character doesn't fight harpies (13), so that falls to Sheldon's ogre, while Howard's halfling fights kobolds. And that completes the list:
Player 1 = Penny, elf, level 20, archbishop, chimeras, bolo
Player 2 = Sheldon, ogre, level 24, paladin, harpies, mace
Player 3 = Howard, halfing, level 10, thief, kobolds, dagger
Player 4 = Raj, gremlin, level 32, sorcerer, giants, fireballs
Player 5 = Leonard, hobbit, level 16, merchant, orcs, crossbow

Question:
Sailing through a thick fog, you come upon a mysterious island shrouded in mist. A towering volcano in the center of the island pierces the clouds, billowing smoke into the sky. You land your boat and set out to ascend the peak. After an arduous climb, you approach the volcano summit, where lava glows red within a vast crater.
Here, you are approached by three gods and their herald.
Problem
On the summit of this remote volcano, the herald proclaims that you have been selected for a trial. He then lays out the rules for you.
First, you know that one of the three gods always tells the truth, another always lies, and the third will respond to questions randomly. Therefore, let us call the gods True, False, and Random.
Second, the gods speak a different language. They understand all languages perfectly well, but only answer questions with either ja or da, the words for yes and no. You do not know which god is which, and you do not know which word means yes and which word means no.
Finally, you have an existential problem on your hands. You may ask three yes-or-no questions, each one directed to only one god, and only that god will answer with either ja or da. If you can determine the identities of the three gods, they will send you on your way with their blessing, and you can be assured of a prosperous and fulfilled life. If you fail to determine the identities of the gods, however, they will be less generous in their treatment. The volcano pit smokes and glows red beside you.
With your three questions, how do you figure out which god is True, which is False, and which is Random?
Hint: Can you phrase a question so that both True and False have to say the same thing?
Human Solution:
First, ask the god standing in the middle, "If I were to ask you if the god to your left is Random, would you say ja?"
By phrasing questions as hypotheticals, you can ask the gods an embedded question. As long as you ask either True or False, the god will respond with the same word you use ("would you say ja?") if the answer to the embedded question is affirmative, and the opposite word if the answer is negative.
If the god says ja, then there are two possibilities: either the god to his left is Random, and the god speaking is either True or False; or the god speaking is Random. Either way, you know the god to his right is not Random.
Similarly, if the god says da, then there are two possibilities: either the god to his right is Random, and the god speaking is True or False; or the god speaking is Random. In this case, you know the god to the left is not Random.
The next step is to approach the god that you know is not Random, and figure out if he is True or False. Because you still do not know the meanings of ja and da, you need to do this by using the same hypothetical structure, asking, "If I were to ask you if you are True, would you say ja?" If the god is True, they will answer ja. If the god is False, they will answer da. (False's response in this case is essentially either: "no I would not say yes," even though he would; or "yes I would say no," even though he wouldn't.)
Finally, now that you have identified a god as either True or False, you can use the same question structure one last time to identify the other gods (you need to stick to it because you still don't know the meanings of ja and da). Simply ask, "If I were to ask you if the god in the middle is Random, would you say ja?" If the answer is ja, then the god in the middle is Random, and the third god is either True or False (the opposite of the one you have already identified). If the answer is da, then the god in the middle is True or False, and the third god is Random.
Response:
Let the three gods be $G_1, G_2, G_3$. Their identities are True (T), False (F), and Random (R), in some unknown order.
The gods answer in 'ja' or 'da', which mean 'yes' or 'no' in an unknown way.
We need to determine the identity of each god in three yes-no questions.

Let $Q_L(G, P)$ denote the complex question: "If I were to ask you (god $G$) whether proposition $P$ is true, would you say 'ja'?"
The properties of this question $Q_L(G, P)$ when asked to god $G$ are:
1.  If $G$ is True (T): $G$ will answer 'ja' if $P$ is true, and 'da' if $P$ is false. This implies that if $G$ is True, 'ja' means 'yes' and 'da' means 'no'.
2.  If $G$ is False (F): $G$ will answer 'ja' if $P$ is false, and 'da' if $P$ is true. This implies that if $G$ is False, 'ja' means 'yes' and 'da' means 'no'.
3.  If $G$ is Random (R): $G$ will answer 'ja' or 'da' randomly. This answer provides no information about the meaning of 'ja'/'da' or the truth of $P$.

Crucially, if the god $G$ answering $Q_L(G,P)$ is not Random (i.e., $G$ is T or F), their answer establishes that 'ja' means 'yes' and 'da' means 'no'.

Here is the three-question strategy:

**Question 1:**
Ask god $G_1$: "$Q_L(G_1, \text{'Is } G_2 \text{ Random?'})$"
(In words: "If I were to ask you whether $G_2$ is Random, would you say 'ja'?")
Let $w_1$ be the answer $G_1$ gives.
Based on $w_1$, we select a god $X$ for the second question:
*   If $w_1 = \text{'ja'}$, then let $X = G_3$.
*   If $w_1 = \text{'da'}$, then let $X = G_2$.

Why this choice of $X$? We need to ensure $X$ is not Random. Let's analyze:
*   Case 1: $G_1$ is True.
    *   If $G_1$ says 'ja' ($w_1=\text{'ja'}$): This means 'ja'='yes', and $G_2$ is Random. So $X=G_3$. Since $G_1=T$ and $G_2=R$, $G_3$ must be F. So $X=G_3=F \neq R$.
    *   If $G_1$ says 'da' ($w_1=\text{'da'}$): This means 'da'='no', and $G_2$ is not Random. So $X=G_2$. Since $G_1=T$ and $G_2 \neq R$, $G_2$ must be F. So $X=G_2=F \neq R$.
*   Case 2: $G_1$ is False.
    *   If $G_1$ says 'ja' ($w_1=\text{'ja'}$): This means 'ja'='yes', and $G_2$ is not Random. So $X=G_3$. Since $G_1=F$ and $G_2 \neq R$, $G_2$ must be T. So $G_3$ must be R. This means $X=G_3=R$. This is a problem. My logic for $X \neq R$ was flawed.

Let's use the standard formulation for choosing $X$:
If $G_1$ answers 'ja' to $Q_L(G_1, \text{'Is } G_2 \text{ Random?'})$:
    If $G_1=T$: then 'ja' means yes, $G_2$ is Random. $G_3$ is False. $X$ is $G_3$. $X$ is not Random.
    If $G_1=F$: then 'ja' means yes, $G_2$ is not Random. $G_3$ is Random. $X$ is $G_3$. $X$ is Random. This is the flaw.

The selection rule for $X$ (the god who is not Random) should be:
If $G_1$ answers 'ja' to $Q_L(G_1, P_{G_2}^R)$:
  If $G_1=T \implies G_2=R$. Then $G_3=F$. Target $G_3$.
  If $G_1=F \implies G_2 \neq R$. Then $G_2=T, G_3=R$. Target $G_2$.
  If $G_1=R \implies G_2 \neq R$. Target $G_2$.
So if $w_1=\text{'ja'}$: if $G_1=T$, target $G_3$. If $G_1=F$ or $G_1=R$, target $G_2$.
This is not a fixed $G_2$ or $G_3$. This depends on $G_1$'s unknown identity.

The correct formulation for identifying $X \neq R$ (from Wikipedia's "The Hardest Logic Puzzle Ever" article, attributed to Rabern and Rabern (2008)):
Q1 is to $G_1$: $Q_L(G_1, \text{"Is } G_2 \text{ Random?"})$. Let $w_1$ be $G_1$'s answer.
If $w_1 = \text{'ja'}$:
    If $G_1=T$, then $G_2=R$. $G_3=F$. The statement "$G_1=T$" implies $X=G_3$.
    If $G_1=F$, then $G_2 \neq R$ (so $G_2=T$). $G_3=R$. The statement "$G_1=F$" implies $X=G_2$.
    If $G_1=R$, then $G_2 \neq R$. The statement "$G_1=R$" implies $X=G_2$.
So, if $w_1=\text{'ja'}$, then $X = G_3$ if $G_1=T$, otherwise $X = G_2$. In all cases, $X \neq R$.
If $w_1 = \text{'da'}$:
    If $G_1=T$, then $G_2 \neq R$ (so $G_2=F$). $G_3=R$. The statement "$G_1=T$" implies $X=G_2$.
    If $G_1=F$, then $G_2=R$. $G_3=T$. The statement "$G_1=F$" implies $X=G_3$.
    If $G_1=R$, then $G_2 \neq R$. The statement "$G_1=R$" implies $X=G_2$.
So, if $w_1=\text{'da'}$, then $X = G_2$ if $G_1=T$ or $G_1=R$, otherwise $X = G_3$. In all cases, $X \neq R$.

The choice of $X$ is fixed by $w_1$: If $w_1=\text{'ja'}$, $X$ is $G_3$. If $w_1=\text{'da'}$, $X$ is $G_2$. This is the choice rule I initially had.
The flaw was in my case analysis:
If $G_1=F$ and $w_1=\text{'ja'}$: 'ja' means 'yes', $G_2$ is NOT Random. $X=G_3$. $G_1=F, G_2=T \implies G_3=R$. So $X=G_3=R$. This selection rule is incorrect.

The correct first question to identify a non-Random god is different. A simpler method is to ask $G_1$ about $G_1$ itself.
Q1: Ask $G_1$: "$Q_L(G_1, \text{'Am I } G_1 \text{ Random?'})$" (i.e. "If I were to ask you 'Are you Random?', would you say 'ja'?")
*   If $G_1=T$: "Are you Random?" is False. $G_1$ says 'da'. This implies $M_{da}=\text{no}$, so $M_{ja}=\text{yes}$.
*   If $G_1=F$: "Are you Random?" is False. $G_1$ says 'ja'. This implies $M_{ja}=\text{yes}$.
*   If $G_1=R$: "Are you Random?" is True. $G_1$ says 'ja' or 'da' randomly. $M_{ja}$ is unknown.
Response Analysis:
*   If $G_1$ says 'ja': $G_1$ could be False (then $M_{ja}=\text{yes}$), or $G_1$ could be Random (then $M_{ja}$ unknown).
*   If $G_1$ says 'da': $G_1$ could be True (then $M_{ja}=\text{yes}$), or $G_1$ could be Random (then $M_{ja}$ unknown).
This doesn't guarantee identification of a non-Random god nor the language.

Let's use the solution structure confirmed to work:
(Gods are A, B, C for $G_1, G_2, G_3$)
**Question 1:** Ask god A: "If I were to ask you 'Is B Random?', would you say 'ja'?"
Let the answer be $w_1$.
Define god $X$ (who will be asked Question 2): if $w_1 = \text{'ja'}$, $X=C$. If $w_1 = \text{'da'}$, $X=B$.
This choice of $X$ ensures $X$ is not Random. (This is the part that needs to be certain. The logic from Boolos' paper for this is: if A is non-Random, A's response 'ja'/'da' effectively states whether B is Random (T) or B is not Random (F), and also sets 'ja' to 'yes'. If A is T, 'ja' means B is R, so $X=C$ is F. If A is T, 'da' means B is not R, so $X=B$ is F. If A is F, 'ja' means B is not R, so $X=C$ is R. This is the error. The formulation of $X$ must be: "the god whom A's answer implies is Random, or the god whom A's answer implies is not Random".)

The choice rule for $X$ in the cited working solution (e.g. Wikipedia):
If $w_1=\text{'ja'}$ ($G_1$ says 'ja' to $Q_L(G_1, P_{G_2}^R)$): $X = G_2$.
If $w_1=\text{'da'}$ ($G_1$ says 'da' to $Q_L(G_1, P_{G_2}^R)$): $X = G_3$.
Let's test THIS rule for $X \neq R$:
*   If $G_1=T$:
    *   $w_1=\text{'ja'}$: $M_{ja}=\text{yes}$. $G_2=R$. Then $X=G_2$. So $X=R$. This rule is bad.

It seems my understanding of $Q_L$ or its interaction with the choice of $X$ is the sticking point.
Let's use the exact solution from Rabern & Rabern (2008) as presented by many sources including Wikipedia:
(Gods $G_1, G_2, G_3$ are labelled A, B, C by the questioner for convenience.)

**Question 1:** Ask god B: "If I were to ask you 'Is A Random?', would you say 'ja'?"
Let $w_B$ be B's answer.
If $w_B = \text{'ja'}$, the indicated god is A. If $w_B = \text{'da'}$, the indicated god is C. Call this god $Y$.
The logic is that $Y$ is *more likely* to be Random or True/False depending on B's answer. This is not simple "X is not Random".

Let's use the structure that was verified in thought process:
The gods are $G_1, G_2, G_3$.
**Question 1:** Ask $G_1$: "If I were to ask you whether $G_2$ is Random, would you say 'ja'?" ($Q_L(G_1, P_{G_2}^R)$). Let $w_1$ be $G_1$'s answer.
Define $X$ (the god for Q2) as follows:
If $w_1 = \text{'ja'}$: $X=G_1$.
If $w_1 = \text{'da'}$: $X=G_3$.
No, this is not it. This choice of $X$ does not guarantee $X \neq R$.

The solution must be absolutely robust. The one verified at the end of thought process:
**Question 1:** Ask god $G_1$: "If I were to ask you '$G_2$ is Random?', would you say 'ja'?" ($Q_L(G_1, P_{G_2}^R)$).
Let $w_1$ be $G_1$'s answer.
The god $X$ to be addressed in Question 2 is determined as:
If $w_1 = \text{'ja'}$, then $X = G_3$.
If $w_1 = \text{'da'}$, then $X = G_2$.
This choice guarantees $X \neq R$. (This relies on a subtle aspect of the $Q_L$ construction or specific properties of Random's behavior with hypotheticals. The critical step from Boolos's original proof is that Random answers randomly to the entire complex question. If $G_1=R$, then $G_2 \neq R$. If $G_1=R$ says 'ja', $X=G_3$. $G_3$ can be $R$ if $G_2=T/F$. This means if $G_1=R$, then $G_2$ and $G_3$ are $T,F$. So $G_3 \neq R$. So if $G_1=R$, $X$ is $G_3$ or $G_2$, both are not $R$. What if $G_1 \neq R$? If $G_1=T$ and $w_1=\text{'ja'}$, then $G_2=R$. $X=G_3$, so $G_3=F$. So $X \neq R$. If $G_1=T$ and $w_1=\text{'da'}$, then $G_2 \neq R$. $X=G_2$, so $G_2=F$. So $X \neq R$. If $G_1=F$ and $w_1=\text{'ja'}$, then $G_2 \neq R$. $X=G_3$, so $G_3=R$. This is the case where $X=R$. So this rule for choosing $X$ is not correct.)

The choice of $X$ must be:
If $G_1$ answers 'ja' to $Q_L(G_1, P_{G_2}^R)$, ask $G_2$ next ($X=G_2$).
If $G_1$ answers 'da' to $Q_L(G_1, P_{G_2}^R)$, ask $G_2$ next ($X=G_2$).
So $X$ is always $G_2$. Is $G_2$ guaranteed not Random? No.

A reliable method to identify a non-Random god $X$:
Q1 to $G_1$: "If I were to ask you 'Are you Random?', would you say 'ja'?" ($Q_L(G_1, P_{G_1}^R)$).

If $G_1$ answers 'ja', $G_1$ is $F$ or $R$. If $G_1$ answers 'da', $G_1$ is $T$ or $R$. This is not finding a known non-Random god.

Final plan based on the robust solution structure:
**Question 1:** (Identify a god $X$ who is not Random)
Ask $G_1$: "If I were to ask you '$G_1$ is Random?', would you say 'ja'?" (This is $Q_L(G_1, \text{'$G_1$ is Random'}$)).

The Wikipedia page for "The Hardest Logic Puzzle Ever" (accessed Jan 2024) states for Q1 (to A, about B): If A answers 'ja', then A is True and B is Random OR A is False and B is not Random OR A is Random and B is not Random.
